00064 /** Returns the width of the terminal where the compiler is running.
00065     Finding this out may fail in a variety of reasonable situations (piping
00066     compiler output to 'less', redirecting output to a file, running the
00067     compiler under a debuffer; in this case, just return a reasonable
00068     default.
00069  */
00070 static int
00071 lTerminalWidth() {
00072 #if defined(ISPC_IS_WINDOWS)
00073     HANDLE h = GetStdHandle(STD_OUTPUT_HANDLE);
00074     if (h == INVALID_HANDLE_VALUE || h == NULL)
00075         return 80;
00076     CONSOLE_SCREEN_BUFFER_INFO bufferInfo = { 0 };
00077     GetConsoleScreenBufferInfo(h, &bufferInfo);
00078     return bufferInfo.dwSize.X;
00079 #else
00080     struct winsize w;
00081     if (ioctl(STDOUT_FILENO, TIOCGWINSZ, &w) < 0)
00082         return 80;
00083     return w.ws_col;
00084 #endif // ISPC_IS_WINDOWS
00085 }

00087 
00088 /** Given a pointer into a string, find the end of the current word and
00089     return a pointer to its last character. 
00090 */
00091 static const char *
00092 lFindWordEnd(const char *buf) {
00093     while (*buf != '\0' && !isspace(*buf))
00094         ++buf;
00095     return buf;
00096 }
00097 
00098 /** When printing error messages, we sometimes want to include the source
00099     file line for context.  This function print the line(s) of the file
00100     corresponding to the provided SourcePos and underlines the range of the
00101     SourcePos with '^' symbols.
00102 */
00103 static void
00104 lPrintFileLineContext(SourcePos p) {
00105     if (p.first_line == 0)
00106         return;
00107 
00108     FILE *f = fopen(p.name, "r");
00109     if (!f)
00110         return;
00111 
00112     int c, curLine = 1;
00113     while ((c = fgetc(f)) != EOF) {
00114         if (curLine >= p.first_line && curLine <= p.last_line)
00115             fputc(c, stderr);
00116         if (c == '\n')
00117             ++curLine;
00118         if (curLine > p.last_line)
00119             break;
00120     }
00121 
00122     int i = 1;
00123     for (; i < p.first_column; ++i)
00124         fputc(' ', stderr);
00125     fputc('^', stderr);
00126     ++i;
00127     for (; i < p.last_column; ++i)
00128         fputc('^', stderr);
00129     fputc('\n', stderr);
00130     fputc('\n', stderr);
00131 
00132     fclose(f);
00133 }
00134 
00135 /** Print the given string to the given FILE, assuming the given output
00136     column width.  Break words as needed to avoid words spilling past the
00137     last column.  */
00138 static void
00139 lPrintWithWordBreaks(const char *buf, int columnWidth, FILE *out) {
00140 #ifdef ISPC_IS_WINDOWS
00141     fputs(buf, out);
00142 #else
00143     int column = 0;
00144     assert(strchr(buf, ':') != NULL);
00145     int indent = strchr(buf, ':') - buf + 2;
00146     int width = std::max(40, columnWidth - 2);
00147 
00148     // Collect everything into a string and print it all at once at the end
00149     // -> try to avoid troubles with mangled error messages with
00150     // multi-threaded builds.
00151     std::string outStr;
00152 
00153     const char *msgPos = buf;
00154     while (true) {
00155         while (*msgPos != '\0' && isspace(*msgPos))
00156             ++msgPos;
00157         if (*msgPos == '\0')
00158             break;
00159 
00160         const char *wordEnd = lFindWordEnd(msgPos);
00161         if (column > indent && column + wordEnd - msgPos > width) {
00162             // This word would overflow, so start a new line
00163             column = indent;
00164             outStr.push_back('\n');
00165             // Indent to the same column as the ":" at the start of the
00166             // message
00167             for (int i = 0; i < indent; ++i)
00168                 outStr.push_back(' ');
00169         }
00170 
00171         // Finally go and copy the word
00172         while (msgPos != wordEnd) {
00173             outStr.push_back(*msgPos++);
00174             ++column;
00175         }
00176         outStr.push_back(' ');
00177         ++column;
00178     }
00179     outStr.push_back('\n');
00180     fputs(outStr.c_str(), out);
00181 #endif
00182 }

00184 
00185 /** Helper function for Error(), Warning(), etc.
00186 
00187     @param type   The type of message being printed (e.g. "Warning")
00188     @param p      Position in source file that is connected to the message
00189                   being printed
00190     @param fmt    printf()-style format string
00191     @param args   Arguments with values for format string % entries
00192 */
00193 static void
00194 lPrint(const char *type, SourcePos p, const char *fmt, va_list args) {
00195 #ifdef ISPC_IS_WINDOWS
00196     char errorBuf[2048], formattedBuf[2048];
00197     if (vsnprintf_s(errorBuf, sizeof(errorBuf), _TRUNCATE, fmt, args) == -1) {
00198         fprintf(stderr, "vsnprintf_s() error!\n");
00199         return;
00200     }
00201 
00202     if (p.first_line == 0) {
00203         // We don't have a valid SourcePos, so create a message without it
00204         if (sprintf_s(formattedBuf, sizeof(formattedBuf), "%s: %s\n", 
00205                        type, errorBuf) == -1) {
00206             fprintf(stderr, "vsnprintf_s() error!\n");
00207             exit(1);
00208         }
00209     }
00210     else {
00211         // Create an error message that includes the file and line number
00212         if (sprintf_s(formattedBuf, sizeof(formattedBuf), "%s(%d): %s: %s\n", 
00213                       p.name, p.first_line, type, errorBuf) == -1) {
00214             fprintf(stderr, "vsnprintf_s() error!\n");
00215             exit(1);
00216         }
00217     }
00218 #else
00219     char *errorBuf, *formattedBuf;
00220     if (vasprintf(&errorBuf, fmt, args) == -1) {
00221         fprintf(stderr, "vasprintf() unable to allocate memory!\n");
00222         abort();
00223     }
00224     if (p.first_line == 0) {
00225         // We don't have a valid SourcePos, so create a message without it
00226         if (asprintf(&formattedBuf, "%s: %s\n", type, errorBuf) == -1) {
00227             fprintf(stderr, "asprintf() unable to allocate memory!\n");
00228             exit(1);
00229         }
00230     }
00231     else {
00232         // Create an error message that includes the file and line number
00233         if (asprintf(&formattedBuf, "%s:%d:%d: %s: %s\n", p.name, 
00234                      p.first_line, p.first_column, type, errorBuf) == -1) {
00235             fprintf(stderr, "asprintf() unable to allocate memory!\n");
00236             exit(1);
00237         }
00238     }
00239 #endif
00240 
00241     // Now that we've done all that work, see if we've already printed the
00242     // exact same error message.  If so, return, so we don't redundantly
00243     // print it and annoy the user.
00244     static std::set<std::string> printed;
00245     if (printed.find(formattedBuf) != printed.end())
00246         return;
00247     printed.insert(formattedBuf);
00248 
00249     lPrintWithWordBreaks(formattedBuf, lTerminalWidth(), stderr);
00250     lPrintFileLineContext(p);
00251 
00252 #ifndef ISPC_IS_WINDOWS
00253     free(errorBuf);
00254     free(formattedBuf);
00255 #endif // !ISPC_IS_WINDOWS
00256 }

00259 void
00260 Error(SourcePos p, const char *fmt, ...) {
00261     va_list args;
00262     va_start(args, fmt);
00263     lPrint("Error", p, fmt, args);
00264     ++m->errorCount;
00265     va_end(args);
00266 }

00269 void
00270 Debug(SourcePos p, const char *fmt, ...) {
00271     if (!g->debugPrint)
00272         return;
00273 
00274     va_list args;
00275     va_start(args, fmt);
00276     lPrint("Debug", p, fmt, args);
00277     va_end(args);
00278 }

00281 void
00282 Warning(SourcePos p, const char *fmt, ...) {
00283     if (g->disableWarnings)
00284         return;
00285 
00286     va_list args;
00287     va_start(args, fmt);
00288     lPrint("Warning", p, fmt, args);
00289     va_end(args);
00290 }

00293 void
00294 PerformanceWarning(SourcePos p, const char *fmt, ...) {
00295     if (!g->emitPerfWarnings)
00296         return;
00297 
00298     va_list args;
00299     va_start(args, fmt);
00300     lPrint("Performance Warning", p, fmt, args);
00301     va_end(args);
00302 }

00305 void
00306 FatalError(const char *file, int line, const char *message) {
00307     fprintf(stderr, "%s(%d): FATAL ERROR: %s\n", file, line, message);
00308     abort();
00309 }

00313 // http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Levenshtein_distance
00314 int
00315 StringEditDistance(const std::string &str1, const std::string &str2, int maxDist) {
00316     int n1 = (int)str1.size(), n2 = (int)str2.size();
00317     int nmax = std::max(n1, n2);
00318 
00319     int *current =  (int *)alloca((nmax+1) * sizeof(int));
00320     int *previous = (int *)alloca((nmax+1) * sizeof(int));
00321 
00322     for (int i = 0; i <= n2; ++i)
00323         previous[i] = i;
00324 
00325     for (int y = 1; y <= n1; ++y) {
00326         current[0] = y;
00327         int rowBest = y;
00328 
00329         for (int x = 1; x <= n2; ++x) {
00330             current[x] = std::min(previous[x-1] + (str1[y-1] == str2[x-1] ? 0 : 1),
00331                                   std::min(current[x-1], previous[x])+1);
00332             rowBest = std::min(rowBest, current[x]);
00333         }
00334 
00335         if (maxDist != 0 && rowBest > maxDist)
00336             return maxDist + 1;
00337 
00338         std::swap(current, previous);
00339     }
00340 
00341     return previous[n2];
00342 }
00343 
00344 
00345 std::vector<std::string> 
00346 MatchStrings(const std::string &str, const std::vector<std::string> &options) {
00347     const int maxDelta = 2;
00348     std::vector<std::string> matches[maxDelta+1];
00349 
00350     // For all of the options that are up to maxDelta edit distance, store
00351     // them in the element of matches[] that corresponds to their edit
00352     // distance.
00353     for (int i = 0; i < (int)options.size(); ++i) {
00354         int dist = StringEditDistance(str, options[i], maxDelta+1);
00355         if (dist <= maxDelta)
00356             matches[dist].push_back(options[i]);
00357     }
00358 
00359     // And return the first one of them, if any, that has at least one
00360     // match.
00361     for (int i = 0; i <= maxDelta; ++i) {
00362         if (matches[i].size())
00363             return matches[i];
00364     }
00365     return std::vector<std::string>();
00366 }

00369 void
00370 GetDirectoryAndFileName(const std::string &currentDirectory, 
00371                         const std::string &relativeName,
00372                         std::string *directory, std::string *filename) {
00373 #ifdef ISPC_IS_WINDOWS
00374     char path[MAX_PATH];
00375     const char *combPath = PathCombine(path, currentDirectory.c_str(),
00376                                        relativeName.c_str());
00377     assert(combPath != NULL);
00378     const char *filenamePtr = PathFindFileName(combPath);
00379     *filename = filenamePtr;
00380     *directory = std::string(combPath, filenamePtr - combPath);
00381 #else
00382     // We need a fully qualified path.  First, see if the current file name
00383     // is fully qualified itself--in that case, the current working
00384     // directory isn't needed.  
00385     // @todo This probably needs to be smarter for Windows...
00386     std::string fullPath;
00387     if (relativeName[0] == '/')
00388         fullPath = relativeName;
00389     else {
00390         fullPath = g->currentDirectory;
00391         if (fullPath[fullPath.size()-1] != '/')
00392             fullPath.push_back('/');
00393         fullPath += relativeName;
00394     }
00395 
00396     // now, we need to separate it into the base name and the directory
00397     const char *fp = fullPath.c_str();
00398     const char *basenameStart = strrchr(fp, '/');
00399     assert(basenameStart != NULL);
00400     ++basenameStart;
00401     assert(basenameStart != '\0');
00402     *filename = basenameStart;
00403     *directory = std::string(fp, basenameStart - fp);
00404 #endif // ISPC_IS_WINDOWS
00405 }
